text:
I've written a few julia scripts (and an accompanying library) for a project I wrote. However they are quite slow-to-start, presumably because of all of the precompilation.
Is there any way I can speed this up? Should I be looking into BinaryBuilder?

elements.text:
I've written a few julia scripts (and an accompanying library) for a project I wrote. However they are quite slow-to-start, presumably because of all of the precompilation.
Is there any way I can speed this up? Should I be looking into BinaryBuilder?

text: Currently there are two ways: ~BinaryBuilder~<https://github.com/JuliaLang/PackageCompiler.jl|PackageCompiler> and <https://github.com/dmolina/DaemonMode.jl|DaemonMode>
BinaryBuilder doesn't have anything to do with that, you're probably thinking about PackageCompiler

elements.text: BinaryBuilder doesn't have anything to do with that, you're probably thinking about PackageCompiler

text: thing #1 is to upgrade to 1.6 if you aren't using it already

elements.text: thing #1 is to upgrade to 1.6 if you aren't using it already

text: well the issue is I'm using 1.6 on my computer, but this is required to run on a system with `1.5.3` only

elements.text: well the issue is I'm using 1.6 on my computer, but this is required to run on a system with

text: It's not dependency hell, but hell of names: of course its PackageCompiler :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: It's not dependency hell, but hell of names: of course its PackageCompiler

text: PackageCompiler compiles packages, BinaryBuilder builds binaries - easy enough to get confused

elements.text: PackageCompiler compiles packages, BinaryBuilder builds binaries - easy enough to get confused

text:
Indeed, I thought I would have to use BinaryBuilder since I would like my executables to be quicker, but I will check out PackageCompiler
thank you!
